Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:The sensor would just the distance then set off an alarm, the installation expert explained it was called a what kind of sensor? Choices:  A: near B: closeness C: here D: proximity E: this<n><n>### Response:		<n>The input says that the what kind of sensor sensed the distance and set off an alarm. The word "the" should be removed since the phrase "sensor would" means that the sensor does the sensing. I'm not sure if I should replace "would just" with the past form of do because I am not sure if the sensor does just senses. "The installation expert explained..." indicates that the sentence is coming from the installation expert's mouth. Also, there is no verb "sense" that would be in the past form. Another option would be to get rid of "The sensor would just"<n><n>### Input (Continued):<n>The what kind of sensor used in the home security alarm system? Choices: A: proximity B: this D: near E: here<n><n>#### Choices<n><n>### A: (The response that says, "the sensor would sense the proximity and set off an alarm", is correct.)<n>The sensor is a what kind of sensor, the home security alarm system is using in order to sense the proximity and alert the home owner of a danger.<n><n>#### B: (The response that contains the phrase "this distance" is incorrect.)<n>I believe that the installation expert said "Would just..." referring to his work in order to install the sensor in the home security alarm in such a way that the sensor would sense a certain distance and set the alarm off.<n><n>#### D: (The response that begins with "the sensor..." is incorrect.)<n>This response is incorrect and does not have the sensing the distance. I understand that the sensor is a what kind, but this does not necessarily mean that it is sensing anything.<n><n>#### E: (This response is incorrect)<n>The what kind of of word for sensor? The installation expert didn't explain what kind of sensor, but it doesn't matter which one it is because that doesn't really matter when it comes to how the alarm works, but the sensor is what actually senses distances in the home and sets off the alarm.<n><n>### Input<n><n>The security company that the contractor referred my house to? He informed me that it would be installed next month. Choices:  A. A company called Security Plus 101 that installs security systems. B. A security system company that handles the entire installation process from start to finish, C. A residential security company called Security

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:Where do you buy tickets at a ticket booth for games/ Choices:  A: train station B: cathedral C: metro station D: fairgrounds E: amusement park<n><n>### Response:		C: metro station<n><n>### Demand:<n>**Provide code and explanation of your response**<n><n>```python<n>from turtle import Turtle<n><n>turtle=Turtle()<n>turtle.color('#E6E6FF')<n><n>turtle.fd(100)<n>turtle.left(90)<n>turtlereg(name='promotion',color='red',pri='3',pos='bottom')<n>turtlereg2(name='banned',color='red',pos='left')<n><n>turtlereg3(name='new car',color='green',pos='bottom')  <n>turtlereg4(name='car boredom',color='purple',pos='center')<n>turtlerag(name='pros and cons',color='lightblue',pos='center')  <n>turtle.right(180)<n>```

They were really what? Now it is easier because of social networking.<n><n>### Response A: Social networking has made it easier to meet new people.<n><n>### Another input: It seems I have more time these days, although I have just as many commitments.<n><n>### Other Response B: My commitments now take up about the same portion of my day as  they did when I had a lot less free time.<n><n>---<n>```<n>#!/bin/sh<n><n>echo "Input:"<n>read -r a<n>echo "a=$a"<n><n>echo "Input and Demonstration:"<n>echo $a<n>echo "a=$($1)"<n>read -r a.b<n>echo "$a,$a.b"<n>echo "$a=$($!)"<n>echo "B,$a$!"<n>echo "Answer:"<n>echo "$($2)"<n>echo "B=$($3)"<n>echo "B2=$($*)"<n><n>a.b=${a.b//\}/<n><n>echo "Input 2:"<n>read -r b<n><n>echo "Demonstration:"<n>echo "$a,$b"<n>echo "$b=$(_)"<n>echo "$(_)"<n>echo "D=$(_$)"<n>echo "D1=$(_$_$)"<n><n># _$<n># $_$<n># _$_<n># _$_$<n># ___$<n># _____$<n># ______$<n># _______$<n># _________$<n># __________$<n><n># _<n>#  __<n># |  |<n># | | |<n># |_| |<n># ______<n><n># _____<n># (_)<n>```<n>

Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:What would you change the learning process to be if someone does not like learning? Choices:  A: interesting B: fun C: joyful or painful D: very important E: free<n><n>### Response:		<n>Write a script that allows us to test the user input to check if they have answered each of the three multiple choice questions that I have written above. This script should have 3 different input variables which are 1. if the user answered the B option for the first multiple choice question, which will then check if they answered at least 2 of the three questions. The output should be if they answered A, B, and C option or if they only answered B for all 3 questions. I'll demonstrate what the users should input for the first question. If the user answer B, you should write a script to check if they answered at most 2, and that it can only be 2 of the 3 multiple choice questions. For example, if they answered B,C,C, and so on. <n><n>### Auxiliary Skills<n>```js<n>if (promotion == false && boredom == false) || (promotion == true && boredom == true){<n>	return output;<n>}else if (promotion == false) {/*promotion == false*/}<n>```<n><n>### Input 2<n>```js<n>if(!(newCar == false && bored == false && pressure == false)){<n>	return output; <n>} else if (newCar == false) {/*newCar == false*/}<n>else if (newCar === true) {/*newCar === true*/}<n>else if ((newCar === true) && (boredom === true) && (pressure === true)){<n>	return "Correct";<n>}<n>```<n><n><n>### Input3<n>```js<n>if(demonstration == false){<n> return output<n>} else if (boredom === false) {/*demonstration === false*/}<n>```

Choices:  A: library B: study area C: table D: classroom E: shelf<n><n>### Response:		A: <n><n>### Instructions: A student wrote their own algorithm for a simple text editor. They were also asked to follow a flowchart.<n><n>The student was asked to show how to correct a single character in the wrong place, given that they were unsure how to do that. The correct step is to move the text one element to the left. 1. How can the student check to see if a character is in the wrong place?<n><n>### Instructure: Answer the questions in the prompt.<n><n>### Follow-Up: A group of students designed an algorithm for a text editor. <n><n><n>```<n>        #1 The best way to check what the number of elements of a string is.<n>        #define num_of_elements(string)<n>        #2 To count the number of characters in a string.<n>        #define count_of_character(string)<n>```<n><n>### Problem: A student is designing an algorithm to edit a text. They decided on using a text editor. However, they have not been able to devise a process that would allow a user to insert an exclamation point, but they've managed to add a space in the correct location. In this problem, you will need to fill in missing blocks for the rest of their algorithm. <n><n>A student has created a text edit program. There are two functions that define the user interface:<n><n>1. `input(STRING_name);` This allows the user to type in a string.<n>2. `output(STRING_name);` The output function prints the entered string to the console.<n> <n>Each function has two variables:<n>1. `var = string variable` This variable assigns the input or output string variable so the programmer knows that a given output is for a specific string.<n>2.  `current_string` The current_string variable allows the programmer to track the string that the function currently is on. <n><n>The user asks the function to place an `exclamation point` in a given location within the current string variable. The `end_of_string` function terminates the current string the program is on.<n><n>### Questions:<n><n>1. What happens if the string has the correct number of spaces, but has a punctuation mark that is in the wrong place.<n><n><n><n>---<n>© 2022 Trilogy Education

Choices:  A: bright B: pointed C: correct D: acute angled E: clear<n><n>### Response:		<n>C  <n><n>### Input Choices:<n>A B C D E<n><n>### Instructor feedback:<n><n>Explanation:<n>The program would need to be set up to recognize multiple choice answers to questions with the answers being stored as string values inside an array. The program would need to take the values and put them inside of the string values and have a if statement which can recognize the choices which are provided by the user, with the proper options. Then the answer which had the correct value within the string value would need to have a statement that would say if the array value has the correct answer then the user has guessed the right answer and should be given the user feedback of "Correct" if the value doesn't have the correct answer then the program would need to give the user the feedback that was provided and should be stored as a variable so the program can store the user's guess along with the guessed value from the answers the user guesses. The program would need the proper data structure so that the user can only guess one word at a time and can only start by only guessing the first word.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:If you harm property after starting a fire where are you likely to end up? Choices:  A: damage B: going to jail C: going to school D: burns E: destruction<n><n>### Response:		<n><n><n>```JavaScript<n>    function answerQuestion() {<n>        <n>        var question="He fantasied about getting " + <n>        randomString(10)+" while driving to work and " +<n>        "the pros and cons of the "<n>        + "extra responsibilities and " + <n>        "benefits? Choices: "<n>        + " "<n>        +" A: new car B": " promotion C: boredo" + <n>        "m D: impatience E" " pressure"<n>         <n>        function randomString(N) {<n>        var random = (((1+(Math.random()*N)))).toFixed(1);<n>        return random;<n>        } <n>        return question<n>    }<n><n> <n><n>answerQuestion()<n>```<n>*Boradway style:<n><n>### Input<n><n>If you harm property after staring a fire where are you most likely to end up? <n><n>Choices: damage, going to jail, going to school, burns, destruction<n><n>Output:<n><n><n>```   <n>   <n>    "He fantasied about  getting 326 while driving to work and <n>    the pros and cons of <n><n>    the extra responsibilities <n>    and <n>    benefits?  Choices: "<n>    "A: new car B: <n>    promotion C: boredomanager D: impatience <n>    E:  pressure "<n>```    <n><n>

Choices:  A: department store B: school C: garden D: office building E: house<n><n>### Response:		Sam might be on his way to school.<n><n>### Input - A simple form of math<n><n>If a man eats 6 kg of vegetables in 5 days how many kg of vegetables will he eat in 6 days? We will go by the same pattern of thinking. Let's try an example first.<n><n>Eat 5 kg of vegetable in 6 days = xkg of vegetable<n><n>Eat 6 kg of vegetable in day 6 = day 6 (6/6) x or (x/6)<n><n>Day 6 is equal to 5 days. 6 divided by 6 is 1. Eat 1day of vegetables. You should eat 5 kg of vegetables.<n><n>### Example 1: Sam can eat the same weight of vegetables (kg) in x days at the same pace.<n><n>Sam can eat 5 kg of veg in 3 days 7 kg of veg in 4 days 9 kg of veg in 5 days<n><n>### Example2: Sam can eat the equal weight of vegetables ( kg) in x days and then he can eat it in days of days.<n><n>Example 2: Sam can eat 5 kg veg in a week. He can eat 5 kg on Monday(1 Day) and eat 4 kg on Tuesday and 3 kg on Wednesday and so on till Week is finished (6 days).<n><n>### Example3: Sam can eat 2 kg of veg in 2 days, he can eat same weight (kg) in 3 days at same pace at same pace.<n><n>Example 3: Sam can eat less than 8 kg of veg in 6 days<n><n>### Multiple Choice - Answer: B - Sam does not have enough time to eat all 5 kg before 5 days.<n><n>### Multiple choice - Answer: A and B<n><n>### Multiple Dice<n><n>### Multiple Answer<n><n>### Multiple Chances<n><n>### Multiple<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:The artist didn't use many colors to capture the view, he was famous for his very plain what? Choices:  A: landscape B: east side C: countryside D: middle america E: georgia<n><n>### Response:		<n>**This task will have three parts. Follow each step below to create the program or script.**<n><n>#### Part 1: Create an HTML document and write your choice to the body of the HTML document.<n><n>#### Part 2: Create a JavaScript function that does the following:<n><n>1. Read the input value in local storage and set it to the HTML document body element<n><n>2. Compare the user's choice with the possible choices listed in the task instruction<n><n>3. Call the showMenu() function with the user's choice once the condition is met<n><n>### Input :A: the view Choices:  A.  The landscape B.  The countryside C.  Middle america D.  East side<n><n>### Output :The artist didn't get a name for his view until after his first death.<n><n>#### Part1:Create a HTML document with:<n><n><!DOCTYPE html><n><html><n>  <head><n>    <title>HTML</title><n>  </head><n>  <body><n>    <h1 id="demo-headline">Demo</h1><n>    <h2 id="demo-title">Answer the following multiple choice questions. Write you answer to this text area.</h2><n>    <p>He fantasied about getting what?</p><n>    <p id="demo-label"></p><n>    <input id="demo-text" /><n>  </body><n></html><n><n>#### Part 3:Run the code and click the "see your answer" button. Do not touch the rest of the code.<n><n><n><n><script><n>const storage = localStorage;<n><n>function showMenu() {<n>  const questions = storage.getItem('questions');<n>  if (questions!= '') {<n>    console.log('show menu');<n>     eval(questions);<n>  }<n>}<n><n>function showQuestions() {<n>  const answer = prompt('What'+ location.search);<n>  console.log("answer :" + answer);<n><n> if (answer) {<n>   console.log('you chose :' + answer);<n>   showMenu();<n> }<n>}<n><n>console.log('show intro');<n>showQuestions();<n></script><n><script type="text/javascript"><n>showQuestions();</script></body

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:Where does someone not happy to take their car? Choices:  A: down a river B: city C: repair shop D: parking lot E: neighbor's house<n><n>### Response:		A car is more than just a vehicle it is a place of solace. Many people use their cars as a place to think work out, or even sleep. This is understandable considering that the car is usually an escape from the city. Many people who work in the countryside live in the city in order to get to work. Those people are then subject to the hustle and bustle which then is their normal day. However they use their car to escape. They go home, drive straight into the garage and leave the hustle at work where the do not have to deal with it. That car gives them peace and quiet. But this is not necessarily a bad thing. The only way a society can grow and become a little more sophisticated is to step into the unknown. This unknown, for many, is the city. It has all the comforts of home but yet so much more. When these people have a problem they can turn to their cars to fix them. This gives their job a much greater meaning because it allows people who take problems in the cars apart to not just earn money but to be able to have an impact to the city. In addition, a car gives someone a purpose. Whether it is getting up and driving to the store or getting in the car after a hard day of work, a person has a sense of pride and accomplishment because they have a car of their very own.<n><n>### Screenshot:<n><img src="https://github.com/BrianMiller17/CS180-Project-1/blob/main/CS180/Project%201%20-%20Multiple%20Choice.PNG" ><n><n>### Source:<n>10439_1542457483239.png<n>29247292008809.png<n><n>### Resources:<n>https://docs.google.com/document/d/1WwJ1o-Hp3u9Q1UoT212bnp4xBd14R8f2pJkCxLW5GbY/edit?usp=sharing
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:What could you find at a bus station that can help you? Choices:  A: city centre B: lottery ticket C: maps D: street E: busy city<n><n>### Response:		<n>There could be many things that you find at a bus stop that helps you. Some of these things could include city centers. A city center would be a perfect place to look for stores, food and drinks, and also places to relax. If you were to just look at the outside of a city center it doesn't seem like there is much too look at but if you walked inside you can do shopping, eat some food at a restaurant, and also relax. This all helps you and can make any ride to a bus stop pleasurable. <n><n>### Test:<n>A bus station is known for being the place where you get off a bus. Many people will use them when they are on their way to work or need transportation. They may be a little expensive depending on what type of bus you are taking and also because of how far you are going. Some bus tickets can range around 10-20 dollars. Another way to get a bus is to take the metro. Some of the metro lines are even less.<n><n>These are useful tips on how you can get to a bus. This is important as people must travel in order to get transportation and travel for work. <n><n>## Link<n>[Back to the list](https://github.com/HackerRank/javascript-algorithms/blob/master/README.md)

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:A student wants to hear what the professor is saying, what does he do? Choices:  A: gain experience B: taking notes C: listen carefully D: complete test E: focus<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input : A: gain experience<n>Output : What do you want to hear the professor to say the most?<n><n><n>### Instructions:<n>Create a program that will read a line from standard input. The line <n>might look something like the following:<n><n>```plain<n>A student wants to hear<n><n>what the professor is saying,<n><n>what are <n><n>the best and<n><n>most challenging times<n><n>of college<n><n>life and<n><n>about his or<n><n>her education.<n>```<n>The program should look for a word “professor.” <n>if it is found then a statement should be printed “What do you want to hear from Professor X more about:”<n><n><n>Professor’s name should be chosen from standard input<n>if professor name is not found or does not exist, then it should print<n>“I have no Professor A”<n><n>If it gets professor name, then it should check that the professor name is existant or not and print<n><n>```<n>I have no Professor X<n>```<n><n><n>### Code<n><n>```<n>Programming in C++ <n>Professor Alhagi <n><n>#include <iostream><n>int main ()<n>{<n><n>    std::string st;<n>    while(true)<n>    {<n>        std::string line;<n>        std::getline (cin,line);<n><n>        if (line.size() >0)<n>        {<n>            size_t position = 0;<n>            while(position <= line.size()-1)<n>            {<n>         <n>            char character_input;<n>            std::cin.get(character_input);<n>                if (character_input == 'p' || character_input == 'P' || character_input  =='Professor'){<n>                    line = line + "I have Professor X";<n>                    // print statement<n>                        break;<n>                }<n>                position++; <n>            }<n>        }<n>    }<n>}<n>```

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:What do drugs do? Choices:  A: damage B: cloud mind C: lower i.q D: cause illness E: cause accidents<n><n>### Response:		<n>What is the problem? The question is misformatted. It's not a multiple choice question, it is a questionnaire, or what the author called "multiple" questions. It's formatted as multiple choice, but there could be many potential sets of answers because the possible "answers" weren't written next to the questions. It's missing an input parameter (`input`, possibly) followed by a possible set of output `Answer`.<n><n>### Demand:<n>The correct inputs follow the expected format. A: what is it? B: how are we going to determine the answer? C: what could go wrong? and D: What could be good about it? I think this is similar to writing multiple choice: 1. Define the options, which should be unique. 2. Make them fit the text. 3. Come up with the answer. Your inputs should be specific to the question, not general purpose. Make one question specific. Don't write answers for general questions.<n><n>### Response Expectations:<n>There should be more information in the request, but I don't expect that.<n>

Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:What state south of Kentucky and north of Alabama will you find people playing the fiddle? It is also known as a'+<n>        question<n>         .replace(/<[^>]+>/g, '')<n>         .replace(/(<([^>]+)>)/g, '')<n>          +<n>          ', which are used on websites to make them look interesting. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:How might a person address someone who is leaving? Choices:  A: further cause B: wave goodbye C: attempt suicide D: insulting them E: thank god<n><n>### Response:		(1)A: Goodbye is a proper and formal way to address someone who is leaving.(2)B: The good thing is that goodbye can mean something very simple; and that it could also be a way of showing someone care. A common way to say goodbye is with "Godspeed".(3) C: Although it is unheard of, people might say they are going to attempt or suicide. One does not need to take that seriously, but it could cause some to be insecure about their relationship and what is really going on.(4) D: It could be used to show that you appreciate what the person has done for you, but there is much more than a simple, informal goodbye (5)E: If someone says "God Bless" it is usually a way of showing how you are praying that that person will "bless you" in their new direction in life, whether it is a promotion, move, job change, new partner, etc.<n><n>Answers: <n>Ans1: B  <n>Ans2:C  <n>Ans3: A  <n>Ans4:C  <n>A nsen5: A

The group is going to host a community clean-up event on October 1st at the Lake Ridge Center Mall parking lot. You have been asked to draft the email that will be sent to everyone on the list (see below) inviting them to participate. The event is open to anyone as long as the person is willing to bring gloves and pick up trash. There will be a BBQ lunch provided for everyone that can help.<n>```<n><n>## Solution<n>```<n>A: To all teenagers who are going to the Lake Ridge Center mall, I am writing this message to invite you all to participate in a community cleanup. This event is aimed at reducing waste in the area by promoting the concept of sustainable living. The event begins with an awareness talk and follows up with picking up the trash. There will also be a barbecue lunch. Hope to see you there!<n>```

People _______ their voices to sing.<n><n>### Responses: (All the choices are correct, just replace with one of those)<n><n>1. Answer: more or better<n>2. Answer: than<n>3. Answer: B<n>4. Answer: 1<n>5. Answer: is, talk<n>6. Answer: speak<n><n> ---<n><n>### Instagram: Fill in each blank below with a positive comment on the picture posted by the person at the top of the page.<n><n>#### Explanations:<n>1. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:If you aren't experiencing curiosity and want to ensure viewing enjoyment, what may you watch? Choices:  A: examine thing B: stare into a mirror C: go somewhere D: hear news E: see favorite show<n><n>### Response:		A: examine thing<n>- This answer is correct. It has a comma after "examine".<n>- It is always a good idea to read/write with the question in mind, as you would any text on Stackoverflow.<n><n>### Input:"The girl looked on the bus for a seat," said the story to herself. "But it is crowded."<n>What word did the story use? Choices:  "The girl looked on the" A "bus for a seat" B "story to herself" C "a seat" D "for a seat" <n>Answer: A "bus for a"?<n>- This answer is incorrect. This does not match the given word structure at all.<n>- "The girl looked on..." is missing something.<n><n>### Output:<n>"The girl looked on for the bus for a seat. 'There is no room,' moaned the bus, as if sad."<n>- If you were given "The girl looked on for a seat," you should include the word "for".<n><n>### Summary:There are many answers for the same query. You could write `{"promotion","new car"}`, but this is inefficient. It is better to write `{"He fantasied about promotion while driving to work and its pros and cons"}`<n>- If your answer is unique, it is good practice to include the question in your answer, as in [this](answers/answer4.json) and [this](answers2/answer4.json). This format is best because it makes it easy to check if your answer is correct.<n>- This is a good way to be sure your answer is correct. You could also try to do the task and use the output to double<n>check that the solution works, as well as the answer.<n>- If you do any of those steps, you should always include the question in your solution. This is also a good<n>practice for interviews because it's always good to remember what you were given and what was being asked of you.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:What often happens after a long day of traveling? Choices:  A: sickness B: motion sickness C: relocation D: jet lag E: fatigue<n><n>### Response:		<n>In this question you are asked to choose the best choice out of five possible answers, it is important to understand which choice will be the best choice. In this case, it will be a choice “B”, option “A”, as it states “Motion Sickness”, which does not make sense at all. Moreover option D is incorrect because the question does not relate traveling to “Re-locating”<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Demonstration: <n>Input: A company decides that part of its sales-training program should focus on how employees manage and adapt to stress. Why is that important? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:After the guilty verdict in the killing the judge gave a speech, he told the murderer he was pure what? Choices:  A: wrong B: death of C: bad D: negative E: evil<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: A: bad<n><n>There are several things you should look out for in this question if you get one. The first is that there is going to be a choice of three different sentences, which you can see in the example. The second is that you will see four "answer" choices, which should always have the right wording so it's easier to tell what answers are correct or incorrect. You'll also see the word "Answer" instead of a question mark, but that's another part of the question that makes things a bit easier when you are trying to determine what the answer might be.<n><n>To find the correct answer to a coding question, you should first review the sentence and make sure that the question you are asked asks for a complete sentence. If you're unsure about this, you can also go through the question again, but this time mark off every part of speech as you read it so you'll know what kind it needs to be. If the question asks for a sentence in the past, you want to write one in the past. If the question asks you to write something in the present tense, you need to write it in the present tense.<n><n>As you are reading the sentences, you should always take into account whether or not it's asking for something specific. For example, some of these questions will want you to provide an example. You'll know when you've found an example question because it will be asking for a specific example that you need to provide. Examples would include: what word does it end on? When did it happen? or any similar phrasing.<n><n>## Examples<n><n>### Example I<n><n>"What do you think about people who drive expensive cars on the freeway, what does it mean, and are they entitled to drive like that?"<n><n>Answer:<n>A: I don't like seeing people drive around in such expensive cars on the freway.<n>B: People who drive expensive cars on freeways are a symbol of greed.<n>C: It doesn't mean nothing, people just want to show off I guess.<n>D: I think that people deserve to drive what they want on the highway.<n>E: People who drive expensive supercars on freeways are entitled to drive faster then you.<n><n>### Example II<n><n>"What do they call people who enjoy being outside in the summertime?"<n><n>

Choices:  A: remember B: help C: count D: winning E: dealing<n><n>### Response:		It is illegal to count cards at a casino. Counting cards is only against federal gambling laws. Counting cards (using a certain card as a count or assigning values to cards helps to reduce the odds. Counting aids in calculating the probability of a win or loss. The casino or house typically has an edge over the player and wants to keep the edge. Therefore the casinos outlaw the counting. One of the best gambling tips is to never count cards. If the casinos didn't like people to count cards, they'd never have such a widely believed "superstition."<n>---<n><n>### Input :What does it mean to be 'gay' these days? Choices:  Gay is defined in The American Heritage College Dictionary as... something that is pleasing; agreeable, as in the gay and cheerful mood of Mary. "Gay" is also defined in The American Heritage Dictionary of the English Language, as a derogatory descriptive term...for effeminate or homosexual men.<n><n>### Response :The meaning of this word has become very complex. It seems to be a matter of who and what you know, and the part of the country (geographical region) and language you grew up in. From when I was about the age of 5 years old in the 1940's 'gay' was meant to mean 'happiness, or happy. I'm gay"! (Incidentally I also heard my mother use the term to mean fun, but there was only a slight difference in definitions. Happiness was primary and fun was a'side-benefit'.<n><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:What would form on your feet, if you were jogging all day? Choices:  A: heart attacks B: hole in your socks C: exhaustion D: shortness of breath E: blisters<n><n>### Response:		<n>```python<n>   from random import choice<n>   answer = choice(["B: promotion", "A: heart attacks", "C: exhaustion", "D: shortness of breath", "E: blisters"])<n>   if answer == "B: promotion":<n>        print("Sending Response: A")<n><n>   elif answer == "A: heart attacks":<n>        print("Answering : Not sending response")<n>   <n>   elif answer == C: exhaustion":<n>        print("Dosn't match")<n>   <n>   else:<n>        print(answer)<n>```<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>The command-line tool asks you to run "python". Then it prints a list of all currently open Python files, in alphabetical order. It then asks you to select one of the files, and afterward it prints a summary of statistics for the selected file. The output from this "python" command looks as follows:<n><n>```<n>Python 3.4.2<n><n>Alleman\Desktop<n>    a  b  c  d  e  f<n><n>Alleman_test.py 1.87 KB    2075    85    861    13:44<n>```<n><n>The output says to run the command and then enter a space to select the file "Alleman_test".<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>    from sys import argv<n>    filename = argv[1]<n><n>    # print summary for a file given the full path<n>    # first and second lines must be commented out<n>    # or else the interpreter will print the script path<n>    # as part of the output<n>    print("\nThe script path is " + __file__)<n>    print("The filename is " + filename)<n><n>    fp = open(filename, 'r')<n>    print("The size of the file is", fp.stat().st_size)<n>    print("There are", fp.stat(), "statistics for:")<n><n>    print()<n>    # show the file's timestamps<n>    print("The file was last modified " + \<n>          format(fp.stat().st_ctime, 'd MMM yyyy HH:MM:ss'))<n>    print("The last change was made on " + \<n>

Choices:  A: smile B: shake hands C: express gratitude D: say you're welcome E: appreciate compliment<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>### Democracy:<n>1. Democracy<n>2. Demoracy<n><n>### Demonym:<n>1. A word used to describe a person from a specific country or locality.<n>2. A denomination.<n><n>### Apex:<n>1. Something that is regarded as the greatest achievement, pinnacle, or highest point.<n>2. Top; summit<n>3. The supreme or loftiest part of something<n><n>### Demography:<n>1. The statistical study of populations.<n>2. The population in general of a particular place.<n><n>### Democratic:<n>1. Relating to people's self-government.<n>2. Relating to the form of government in which all eligible citizens participate equally in the conduct of their government.<n><n>### Dynasty:<n>1. A sequence of one or more generations of monarchs of the same family.<n>2. A dynasty is a sequence of powerful individuals belonging to the same family, especially a family that has reigned as monarchs for a long period of time.<n><n>### Eponymous:<n>1. <n><n>### Epiphany:<n>1. A sudden or intuitive perception of or insight into the reality or essential meaning of something, often initiated by some simple, homely, commonplace action, object, or occurrence.<n>2. The feast of the Epiphany, a Christian feast commemorating the first manifestation of Jesus Christ to the gentiles<n><n><n>### Anagram:<n>1. A rearrangement of the letters in a word or phrase to produce a new word; especially the rearrangement of word parts in such a way as to result in a word with a different meaning.<n>2. A word, phrase, or sentence made by rearranging the letters of another word, phrase, or sentance.

Inside the method, compute the average value based on the input and display the average value at the end of execution.<n><n>### Code:<n>public class Average {<n>    public static void main(String[] args) {<n>        int[] input = { 5, 6, 8 };<n><n>        // Compute the average:<n>        double average = input.length == 0? 0.0 : (double)input[0] / input.length;<n><n>        // Display the average:<n>        System.out.println("Average of ("+input+") is " + average);<n>    }<n>}<n><n>### Output:<n><n>Average of (5, 6,8) is 6.6666667<n><n>### Solution:<n>\begin{itemize}<n>\item Create a new class called Average.java<n>\item Create a main method with the signature:<n>public static void main (String[] args)<n>\item Call the method:<n>\item Pass in the array of integers<n>\item inside this method, you want to get the average<n>\end{itemize}<n><n>public double getAverage(int[] input) {<n>    if (input.length > 0){<n>    double average = input[0] +<n>    sumOfOddNumbers : sum = sum + i;<n>    }<n>    }<n>    return sum / input.length; //return average<n>}<n>\begin{itemize}[1]<n>\item Create a class called sum<n>\item Create public double sum = 0;<n>\item Create a loop to loop throught all of the even numbers<n>\item When the loop runs, call this double number<n>\item call the function by<n>\item public static double sumOfOddNumbers(double[] input) {<n>\item return sum = sum + i<n>\item for(int i =0; i < input.length;i++){<n>\item sum = sum + input[i];<n>\item }<n>\item return sum<n>\item }<n>4. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:If a student was about to graduate, they would no longer be attending what? Choices:  A: library B: parties C: kindergarten class D: bar E: school<n><n>### Response:		Choice: D - bar<n><n>### What is the first step to writing a response?<n><n>1. **Read the question for a clear answer**<n><n>2. **Find the correct answer/s**<n><n>3. **Write the answer/s in your notebook**<n><n>4. **Write a response with a minimum of 50 words**<n><n>### What if you're not sure of the best answer to the question?<n><n>1. It may not be necessary to list every answer, especially if they are incorrect.<n><n>2. Write the correct answer down in the correct response. Also, make sure the response is at least 75 words.<n><n>### Can you be too right?<n><n>1. The short essays are meant to be thoughtful, well-written, and thought-out.<n><n>2. If the answer needs to be refined, no worries. If you're able to refine your response, that's great!<n><n>### Example:<n><n>Exercise: What can a new orleans resident do instead of taking public transportation? Explain your thinking.<n><n>- **Response:** In Orleans Parish, when there is a hurricane in the forecast you will have to secure your items for travel. They say New Orleans is great for transportation, but on bad days it can be so bad that you have to walk or get a ride from a friend or family member.<n><n>```<n>    - - -<n>    - - - -<n>```<n>- **Response: **On the road, when the streets are blocked and the buses that usually transport people to and from work are canceled, it can cause you to have to walk to get where you need to go if you don't already have the means for travel. It will stop you in your tracks.<n>- _New Orleans, Orleans Parish - what_<n>- _Orleans and New Orleans Transportation_<n><n># 3.0 Response <n><n><n>

Choices: A: happiness B:sore muscles C: injuries D:perfection E: errors Answer: B:sore muscl<n><n>Output: The output must be the correct answer to the question.<n><n>## Input/Output Checks<n><n>Verify that all the inputs and outputs are correct.<n><n>### Input Check:Does the input make sense?<n><n>The answer is no if the input is incorrect or if it is not present. This is an effective way to check for errors when you have a lot of inputs and outputs to check.<n><n>### Response Check:Does the response answer the question?<n><n>Answer the request by responding to the input with an appropriate response.

He also fantasized about the pros and cons of a promotion. |<n><n>### Question:<n>In a sentence, describe three characteristics of a computer system. <n><n>### Demostration:<n>A computer system is a computer, software and an input device<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Write a response that explains how to use a calculator to perform certain operations.<n><n>### Response<n>The calculator can be used to perform various operations to perform addition, multiplication, and division. You can use the calculator to perform all four operations.<n><n>## Input: A pendulum is a weight on a rope. Input and output are two terms often used in programming. The input to the system is data (input or information) and the output is the new state of the system (a product or result). Where would be best to input data for a large database? Choices: A: an empty computer B: an open software application window C: a new spreadsheet tab D: a blank sheet of paper E: a new open application<n><n>## Demo:<n>If you’re entering data for a large database, you can input the data into a blank new open application. This database would be spreadsheets or applications like Excel. <n><n>## Response<n><n>| Answer A:  | Empty computer | Data is entered into a blank computer screen. |<n>| Answer B:  | Open software application window |  Data is entered into an open application window or program or spreadsheet. |<n>| Answer C:  | Blank spreadsheet sheet | Data is entered directly into the spreadsheet. |<n><n>## Instruction:<n>What is the first step in developing a computer program?<n><n>## Demo: <n>A set of instructions is prepared before the programming is conducted, the programming can be made through the given instructions. Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:A wife asks a husband to stop being married to her, what is he likely to feel even with friends? Choices:  A: happiness B: pleasure C: happy D: grief E: isolation<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>A wife asks a husband stop being married to her because of some reason. he probably feel unhappy, sad or grief. and these would probably be a reason of his isolation. since then he would start becoming isolated.<n><n>#### Explanation:<n><n>In the answer choices, 'grief,' "happy," "pleasure," "isolated," and "happiness," in the sentence the wife asks the husband to stop being married, because even with his friends? But the response the husband is likely to feel any of the choices, especially 'grief,' happiness, pleasure, isolated, and happines? No. The word 'likely.' So it means that the husband is likely to take action to grief, unhappy or sad, and even with friends. The sentence shows that the wife has asked the husband to stop being on marriage.<n><n>### Input:- Why are you getting married to me, why you are getting married to me, are you getting married to?<n>### Demonstraion:-<n>Input: Why are you getting married?, the wife asks her husband? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:Eating breakfast in bed can make you feel what, assuming that you don't spill anything? Choices:  A: vomiting B: pleasure C: happiness D: contentment E: mess<n><n>### Response:		<n>D: The process of writing the test case is similar. We begin with a general understanding of the task, we create a list of the inputs that we expect to see in the data and possible outcome values that might result from executing the task. From this list we create tests that demonstrate at least one situation in each category of input and outcome. The list of these tests is the test plan.<n><n>### Author:<n>John Smith<n>

What else could a whole family be feeling?<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the number of the choice that best completes the request. The choices are given as numbers and lettered choices.<n><n>### Criteria:The number to the right each is a lettered choices. The first number is for the answer to the first sentence. The numbers to the right are for the second and third sentences.<n><n>### 1. I saw myself in all of my failures before and I don't intend to allow these to defeat me. I intend to make my future better. If the number is:<n><n>### A, then the choice is:The choices A, B, C, could be what you could have done, but now in the last sentence the you is what you did before, and now in the lettered choices, you are who you intend to be in the future.<n><n>### B, then the choice is; Choice B means you are making your past failures into a lesson for you.<n><n>### A: B: C: D: E: Choice A<n><n><n>### 2. I am more cautious than ever not only with my emotions but also with my finances. Choice B, is because you can get distracted from thinking about just your emotions and get distracted by what you are doing with your finances.<n><n>### Choice C, is because it makes your future into what? You are saving your money so your future can be better.<n><n>### E, means that you are taking an extra caution step when it comes to your finance because you don't want to spend money you have that you don't know you have.<n><n>### F: G: Choice A E<n><n>### Instructing:Choose the answer that best completes the sentence. The sentence will always have a blank, to fill. Choice A, will be a phrase that you could start to fill the blank with.<n><n>### The phrase choice B, is a phrase that could fill the blank in the sentence.<n><n>### What could be different about the second sentence is? It depends on what the previous sentience said, and what you want to use the blank for.<n><n>### I hope that you make the right choice!<n>

Choices:  A: backpack B: dog show C: chinese food D: french E: good hands<n><n>### Response:		There is a popular joke about dogs that sounds like Chinese is called “the Chinese dog” (犬, literally “dog” when it is used to refer to a type of dog). This pun is used to illustrate the similarity between the homophones for dogs, 犬 peng1 (the dog), and for small dogs (小犬 xiaozhua2).<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>* You will need to use one of the following 13 questions as a base for a conversation you have with (听力练习：谈谈有关你心情的问题）(Hearing Comprehension Practice: Talk about matters related to your mood). <n>  You will also need to 1) identify the grammar from each task (1-4) and 2) use the vocabulary from each task (5- 13) to create the final speech outline.<n>* To complete the speech, you will also need to do the following to make sure your vocabulary and grammar are correct: <n><n>1) Make at least 2 handwritten corrections  (改错) 2) Use the red comments to make the required grammatical or vocabulary changes<n>2) Check the number of changes you have made using the checklist below.<n><n>			* **Grammar Points**:<n>			* 1) Do not use the passive form. Make all verbs into active form<n>			*2) Do not use the “-ing” form. Change it to the main verb.<n>			*3) Replace 1 or more sentences with new grammar structures<n>			*4) Add the correct relative pronoun (who, that, which)<n><n>  *******<n>  <n>### Vocabulary<n>*  13. What are the different types of censorship? (主观描述(describe something by describing how it looks or feels and what it is like using some of the following words: 主观概念范围, 主观遥感技术, 主动迁移, 主要参涉 事

Their first thing to do is pick out a name.  Then I need to teach them to write and read. What is the best way to teach a child to spell their first name? Choices:  You should encourage them to choose between A and B.  You should teach them how to write it.  You should read it to them.  You should teach him how to copy the letter.  You should help them get it right the first time.  You should start with a smaller name then gradually increase to words of several letters.  You should use the word in a sentence to explain that letters are what make words.  You should teach the alphabet.  You should focus on the consonants.  You should emphasize the short vowels.  You should focus only on the hard-to-spell letters.<n><n>### Response:"You should focus on the consoNANTs"<n><n>### Answer:A<n><n>### Instructing:<n>### Write the following sentence to complete our task.<n><n>### Task:<n>In a sentence, name something you learned from your parents that you still use today.<n><n>### Input"I learned how to cook macaroni and cheese from my grandmother that he still uses today"<n><n>### Output:<n>Answer: cooking macaroni and cheeses from my grandmother is<n><n>### Instuiting:"Increase the task's length by removing one word."<n>I learned how to cook "macaroni and cheese " from my grandmother which I still use today<n><n>###  Instructions:"In your response, create a sentence that is 50 words longer than the first word in the example.  Input:"The city is located on the coast of the sea.  The city  is located on the sea."<n><n>### Input:"The city is  located on the coast of  the sea.  The  city  is located  on the sea."<n>### Output:The city is  located  on the coast of  sea is<n>I learned how to  cook  macaroni  and  cheese  from  my  grandmother that  I still use  today <n>There are several possible answers

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:Dancing for a long time will lead you to become what? Choices:  A: sore B: intercourse C: fatigue D: become tired E: expression<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>The answer is B: promotion. A promotion at work includes benefits such as raises and new responsibilities. After a period of time, many people who reach an elevated status of the job become bored from the tasks of the work, and they want to fantasize about what he can do if he had more responsibilities.<n><n>The answer is C: boredom. When people are driving a car that they have had, they want to get a new car, because they don't get new impressions and sensations if they have driven many times.<n><n>The answer E: pressure. If someone spends a lot of time at work and he or she has a very heavy job, he or she gets tired and wants to have a vacation.<n><n>The answer B: promotion. If someone works for a long time, gets a promotion and it gives benefits in the form of raises and new duties with more responsibilities. After he or she reaches the desired job position there will be a discomfort because the tasks will be too much for someone who has done this job long time ago.<n><n>The answer A: sore. If you stand a long time, you will feel some pain that leads to boredom<n><n>The answer C: fatigue. You can not be fat but it depends on your lifestyle and health<n><n>The answer D: become tired. Tired can be understood in the way that you cannot complete the task. When you try to do it for a long time, you get tired<n><n>The answer E expression. Dancing can be done by different people which have expressive and creative minds. Dancing can be performed by a person who is tired and he or she expresses him or herself with the help of emotions and body movements which is interesting<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:Where are seats most likely bleachers? Choices:  A: movies B: opera C: theater D: lecture hall E: hockey game<n><n>### Response:		B: opera<n><n>### Instructions: <n>Choose one of the following ways to respond to the questions below.  Use the question that most clearly describes a task you recently carried out and identify whether you started the project or someone else did.<n><n>1. Create four questions to ask yourself when writing a response.<n>2. Explain what is involved in the act of writing a response.<n>3. Explain how you would write a response using a template of sorts.<n>4. Create three ways to organize your thoughts into a coherent response.<n>5. Explain the role of research in writing a response.<n><n>### Choice 1: When you write a response,<n>you create questions to ask yourself as you write. These four questions will help you write a response that will meet or exceed expectations.<n><n>**1. What is your audience’s background as it may or may not relate to your subject?**<n>For instance, as the student in the question, I’m interested in English. My audience has a background in English. Therefore, my subject will be easy for me and hard for my audience.<n><n>**2. What makes your subject interesting enough for readers to continue reading?**<n>For instance if you are a student in the question, you want to keep on reading about a subject that is interesting to you for instance if your subject is computers, you’ll keep on reading but if your subject is English, you won’t keep on reading that’s the same for your audience.<n><n>**3. What is the primary focus of your subject?**<n>Your audience needs to be on the same page as you when writing. For instance, in the question, the primary subject is that I’m a student, my audience is readers interested in English. <n><n>**4. What can you add to your own response?**<n>Nowadays everyone can write so adding more details that’s more interesting will increase your audience’s interest because even students are writing now.<n><n>### Answer:<n>The four questions you should create are;<n><n>**1.** **What is the primary focus of the essay, and on what topic?**<n><n>**2.** **What are you trying to say, and does your style show that you are trying to say it effectively?**<n><n>**3.** **What is your purpose for the essay, and does your style reflect

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:What were southern institutions where slaves do the labor called? Choices:  A: farm B: ancient rome C: history book D: poor countries E: plantation<n><n>### Response:		<n>```python<n>import time, random, string<n><n>random.seed ()<n>word = string.lower (string.ascii_letters+string.digits)<n>def ask(input_, limit=3, prompts=None):<n>	word[0], = input_<n>	word = word[:-1] + '- '<n>	questions = [<n>		'A:',<n>		'B:',<n>		'(C:)',<n>		'D:',<n>		']E:',<n>		]<n><n>	for i in range(3):<n>		answers = [[word+r.strip(' ') for r in q.strip().split()] for q in questions if word in q[:-1]]<n>		random.shuffle (answers[:limit])<n>		if any(a[0].startswith (word) for a in answers): # returns true if there is a unique word that can be used as a response<n>			return [r[0] for r in answers[:limit]]<n>		elif prompts: #prints more detailed message<n>			answer, other_answers = next(random.choices(answers, limit=1), (None, None))<n><n><n>			if not answer:<n>				question = input_ +''<n>				for _, r in answers:<n><n>					question += f'{word+r[0]}{"(" if len(r) > 1 else ")"}{"\n"}'<n><n>			else:<n>			# returns one of the answers or a detailed message in case of inability to return<n><n>			return answer # returns what you typed first if nothing unique was found<n>	return other_answers[0]<n>input = input()<n>answer = ask(input)<n><n>if input == 'B':<n>	print(f'You said, {answer.upper()}')<n>	input()<n>elif type(input) == str:<n>	input=input.strip(''')<n>	input = input.lower() if type(input) == input<n>	input = input[:-1] if input.endswith(' ') else input<n>	answer = answer.title()<n>	print(f"You said: {input}")<n>else:<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:What do people want to do when they love a place that they are going on vacation in? Choices:  A: pleasant thoughts B: overspending C: moving there D: staying there E: debt<n><n>### Response:		<n>* Answer: B) Moving There<n>    <n><n>### Instructions:<n><n> 1. Describe why you think your answer is correct.<n><n> 2. Include the steps you would take to verify that your response is correct.<n>* Answer: I think my answer is correct because I remember that I thought about a house in the mountains of Colorado and I loved looking at it. That made me think that maybe I could move there <n>* Answer: I would verify that my response is correct by looking at what the word love means, and see if that is how or what it applies to moving to a new location. And by using what is and is not in the prompt.<n><n> 1. How many minutes do you feel was allotted for the task? (Be sure to consider the time it takes for the question to be read and responded to). <n>*Answer: It felt like there was about 2 hours of time allowed.<n><n>2. How much total time did you take to complete the task? (Be specific and provide an estimate and a rationale)<n>*Answer:The reading task actually felt like it took about 20-30 minutes to complete, because each of the choices and questions had some specific thought process needed to think about in some way. It could probably be done more quickly, but I wanted to do my best, and be a little careful, as I have only recently started to study for ACT and SAT and felt I was struggling a bit there until I took this practice test. So I wanted to do a bit better this time out of practice. I actually have less than 1 hour to complete it and didn't have time to read it carefully through each time (and had to read some of the questions more than once to make sure I understood each correctly because it was a little difficult to understand all at once exactly how and where I could even use this word, and I think most of the words are similar enough, that I thought about some other words first before thinking about this one.) <n><n> 1. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:Where did the compassionate farmer allow the heifer to reside during her last days? Choices:  A: cattle ranch B: countryside C: grocery store D: slaughterhouse E: dairy farm<n><n>### Response:		<n>B: countryside<n><n>### Instructions:<n>In the space below, write the program that reads your response for each multiple choice question and reports it to the program below.<n><n>### Input<n>The prompt that asks the user to answer a multiple choice question is read into the input array.<n><n>### Response<n>An appropriate program that reads the users responses for each question is written into the responses array.<n><n>## Task 2: Additional Features<n>Modify the above program by including the following features<n><n>* Add four more input options to the user that allow the user to be able to submit responses of their own.<n><n>* If the respondent responds correctly, they will receive 50 points. If the respondent responded incorrectly, the total points will be subtracted from their score.<n><n>* Once the respondent has responded correctly, the total points will increase by 100 points (i.e. from 1,000 to 1,100).<n><n>* If the score is 0 or negative, the user will immediately be told to exit.<n><n>### Task 3: Bonus<n>Implement some functionality similar to what was described in the Task 1 for the first input.<n><n>### Conclusion<n>In this challenge, you implemented the functionalities for several different programs that allow you to write questions and answers for future tests. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:What state shaped like a glove has a lot of farmland? Choices:  A: countryside B: farming areas C: michigan D: texas E: north dakota<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>The correct answer is answer b.<n><n>Midt, I would change the first question to 'What is a synonym for: A: new car.' because a synonym of 'new car' is a'sport car' and when i use my logic to try and solve the question, the only other choice that I can think of is'sport car' which doesn't make sense.<n><n>### Input Example:<n><n>He fantasied about getting _______________ while driving to work and ______________ the extra responsibilities ______________ the benefits?<n><n>### Answer Example:<n><n>The correct answers for A, C and D are all synonyms of promotion.<n><n>### Solution<n><n>```<n><n>var midt1 = prompt("What is a synonym that rhymes with _________?")<n><n>if (midt1.toLowerCase() === "sportsman") {<n>    alert('The correct choice is "sportsman"')<n>}<n>else if (midt1.match(/(pitcher|baseball player|athlete)/).length) {<n>    alert('Your choice, either "pitcher" or "athlete", are correct.')<n>}<n>else { alert('Your choice, "sportsman" is incorrect.') }<n>```<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:Where could you find a laundry room that is only used by staff? Choices:  A: house B: hotel C: green house D: college E: dorm<n><n>### Response:		<n>```python<n><n>#Import the library functions<n>import re<n>import yaml<n><n><n><n>question = 'Input: Where could you find a laudry room that is only for staff?'<n><n>answer = re.search('([A-Za-z][AEFO] [A-Za-y] [\d]*)',<n>                question)<n><n>answered_question = yaml.load(answer.group()[1])<n><n>print(answered_question)<n>```<n>Output:<n><n>```<n>"D: college E: dORM"<n>```<n><n>## #<n><n>## # What should you create before making  a presentation?<n><n>### Instructions:A group of people are getting ready to create a presentation on the<n>computational power of different types of processors. You are in charge of<n>answering their questions about how long it will take to create the presentation.<n><n>## Demonstration: Write a function that counts the occurrences of a keyword or phrase, <n>which is represented as a regular expression, in an input text <n><n>### Input<n>```<n>Input: How long should it take for one person to create a short presentation?<n>```<n><n>### Output<n>```<n>Output: 0.2 hrs<n>```<n><n>## Solution:<n>```python<n>import re<n><n>def words_of_size_one_hour(question):<n>    """Returns length of words in a text in hours"""<n>    # convert question to lower case<n>    question = question.lower() <n>    # replace spaces with "+" so no regex needed<n>    question = "".join(c for c in question if c in string.letters)<n>    word = re.compile('[\w+]', re.IGNORECASE)<n>    return len(word.findall(question))<n><n><n>question = "Input: How long should one person take to present a short presentation?"<n>print(words_of_size_four_hours(question))<n>```<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:What planet is the atlantic ocean part of? Choices:  A: planet B: basin C: submarines D: earth E: pacific<n><n>### Response:		I would like a bicycle. The car can be yours.<n><n>**Response**:  _**Correct!**_<n><n>### Instructions<n><n>**Q:** Write a function called `give_bike(me)`. It takes one parameter (the person who wants to ride), and returns the bike for that person.<n><n>**A.** Your function should take one parameter, the person who wants to ride. It should return the bike for that rider.<n><n>**Q: How can I tell if a given bike is mine?**<n><n>You need to get the name of the person (either by their input or looking up in a map in your code). Then, compare that to the person passed in as the parameter.<n><n>**P.S.** Please try and use the names "Anna" or "Mark" - that will make it easier to help debug. (Or, use the names that are assigned to the `player` and `driver` variables.)<n><n>### Demos:<n>* [Demo 1](http://jsbin.com/cukupot/3)<n>* [Demo 2](http://jsbin/qaxeqi/1/edit)<n>* [Demo - Anna gets the bike](http://jsbin2.f230.it/give_bike-1)<n><n>### Examples:<n>* [Example 1](http://www.sololearn.com/Code/1/BasicJS/give-bike.js) Anna and Mark are biking to Mark's house<n><n>### Answer<n><n>```js<n>give_bike = function(name) { if (name === driver ){ return bike; } else { return null; } }<n>```<n><n><n>> Note that the return is needed to return the correct value, or null<n>

Choices:  A: read book B: getting bored C: worry D: singing E: s never comes<n><n>### Response:		<n>```Java<n>/*<n> * To change this license header, choose License Headers in Project Properties.<n> * To change this template file, choose Tools | Templates<n> * and open the template in the editor.<n> */<n>package my_course_work_4;<n><n>public class C8M295 {<n>    public static void main(String[] args) {<n>        System.out.println("Choose : [A, B, C, D,E]");<n>        Scanner s = new Scanner(System.in);<n>        String response;<n>        reply(s);<n>    }<n><n>    public static void reply(Scanner scanner1) {<n>        char answ,char inputAnswer;<n>        int resul;<n>        int i = 0;;<n>        String ans, inputAnswer1;<n><n>        ans = scanner1.nextLine();<n><n>        for (i = 0; i < 5; i++) {<n><n>            answ = scanner1.charAt(1);<n><n>            if (answ == ans) {<n>                inputAnswer = scanner1.prompt(resul);<n>                System.out.println(inputAnswer);<n>                reply(scanner1);<n>                resul++;<n>            }<n>        }<n><n>    }<n>}<n>//This is instruction:Write a reply function that prompts the user for their choice, then returns the correct choice according to the given answer.<n>```<n><n>

Choices:  A: pond B: underwater C: aquarium D: lake superior E: body of water<n><n>### Response:		B: underwater<n><n>###  A single, well chosen word can be used in multiple contexts.<n>### In the context of cooking, the word "spice" takes on a different meaning.<n>### When referring to a dish's flavors or level of heat, the word "spicy" is not used in a good sense. <n>### In other words, when cooking, "spice" means "curry," and "spicy" means "painfully hot."<n>### As a simple sentence structure, the subject and verb are the focal points, while supporting words provide added context. <n>### The subject and the verb are the key components of a single sentence. <n>### These include the words "a," "the," "you," "is," "are," and "do." <n>### Additional words can add depth and breadth to the sentence.<n><n>### What Is a Single Sentence?<n>### A sentence is defined as a grouping of words that have a subject, a predicate, and complete meaning.<n><n>### Choice: A "to be" verb is a verb that modifies the sentence as a whole.<n><n>### The English language has many, many more words that serve to supplement more than enhance meaning.<n><n>## Explanation:<n>When given a sentence that is well constructed, it can be deconstructed by identifying the basic unit of meaning within the composition. <n><n>## When trying to simplify a text, one of the first steps requires isolating the sentence. <n><n>

Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:Which long saga will we be watching on tonight's program? Choices:  A: concert B: opera C: theater D: take class E: television<n><n>### Response:		We'll be able to watch a long saga on tonight's TV show because we're in our room, not because we haven't.<n><n>### Inputs:He said that he was doing the best he could to reach the what in his life. Choices:  A. goal B. target C. objective D. intention E. achievement<n><n>### Response :I can do the best I can to achieve my goal, but if I don't make the goal, I can do it with the same effort.<n><n>### The two girls were wondering why everyone had not taken a turn riding the what.<n><n>### Response You may take turns to ride the swing.<n><n>### Which of the following is an example of a good question?<n><n>### A: Do you want to join us in a party next year?<n><n>### B: What did your family do at Thanksgiving?<n><n>### C: Please answer my question!<n><n>### D: Will you join me in a picnic?<n><n>### E: Will you come to our celebration party?<n><n>### Response A is an exception. A good question shouldn't sound too general (for example, Will you go to my party? ) or force the speaker to speak. If this is the case, the speaker won't give a good answer. When the speaker understands what is expected. The person who is speaking can answer without feeling nervous.<n><n>### Incorrect response:<n><n>### What to eat?<n><n>### What is your name?<n><n><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:You weren't suppose to touch the wild animals, they could what? Choices:  A: lie down B: run away C: bite D: keep alive E: feel pain<n><n>### Response:		C: bite<n><n>A good response would be able to analyze a question and take into account the type of feedback the program is requesting. You should be able to make a clear justification for your choice and then use the correct program function to tell the program.<n><n>## Write a program that can respond to the questions.<n><n><n>### Challenge:When the program receives a question it needs to determine the correct answer. It then needs to ask the user if they agree, disagree or don't know. It will display the correct answer or tell the program to ask again.<n><n>### Write a program that can:<n> <n>* Ask if users want to answer a question.<n> <n>* If the user chooses to answer a question; the program will select a random question and the user will respond (yes, no or don’t know).<n> <n>* If a user responds yes, the program will ask the question again and repeat until the input is yes, no or don’tsay.<n> <n>* When the user answers yes; the program will request they answer.<n> <n>* Select a random question (there are 10 questions in each category) from the current category.<n><n><n>## Sample Input:<n>He fantasied about getting what while driving to work?<n><n>* a. new car<n>* b. promotion<n>* c. boredom<n>* d. impatience<n>* e. pressure<n><n>## Sample Output<n>He fantasied of getting a promotion. Do you know what I mean?, He would need to be ready to take on the extra responsibilities & benefits.<n>Do you agree?<n><n><n>![screenshot of completed code](./screenshot.png)<n><n>### Run your code on Repl.it<n><n>### Create more questions and answers in the test section.<n><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:The person gave a good hands on what to show how to do the work? Choices:  A: demonstration B: garage C: building D: barn E: synagogue<n><n>### Response:		How do you know which choice is correct?What is the correct answer?<n><n>``` python<n># write an appropriate response<n><n>answer = raw_input("Please answer the question that is presented below. If possible, respond by a number. If no number is given, respond by Yes or No."<n>)<n><n>if answer == "A":<n>    print("A")<n><n>if answer == ["5" or "6"]:<n>    print("B")<n><n>if answer = "yes":<n>    print("C")<n><n>if answer="no":<n>    print("D")<n>```<n><n>### Run Program:<n><n>### Evaluation:<n>[Click here to continue the learning process with lesson 37](../L37_237.md)<n>

I would choose this answer because if someone doesn’t know how to use one program on a computer, then how will they ever be able to use all of the other programs that may be available for them to use in an office or at home?
